newsitem.title: USA: US OPTIONS FOCUS - Sentiment mixed on high techs.
newsitem.headline: US OPTIONS FOCUS - Sentiment mixed on high techs.

text.p: The recent selloff in U.S. technology stocks gathered steam Wednesday, but options investors were buying and selling as sentiment on the overall group remained mixed, traders said.
In late trading, the Nasdaq 100 index was down 16.05 points, or nearly two percent, at 811.52. It reached a session low of 798.25 before recovering.
The index is comprised of the 100 largest non-financial stocks listed on the Nasdaq stock market. NDX options trade at the Chicago Board Options Exchange (CBOE).
NDX options are not frequently active, but on Wednesday, traders said activity was heavy, particularly in the March series, which expires at the end of the week.
The March 830 call was most active with turnover of about 2,420 contracts. The march 820 call traded 2,385 and the March 820 put traded 2,130.
Trading was steady in most April options as well as select May contracts.
One NDX options trader said investors were on both sides of the market, buying and selling the calls and puts.
He added that some of the heavy March action was likely from investors closing out positions, some of which were most likely rolled out into April.
"They're bouncing all over the lot," Hank Nothnagel, head of options trading at EVEREN Securities, said of some of the NDX options. "Big swings and big spreads."
Jesse Stamer, a general partner at TradeNet in Chicago, said some investors were taking profits on puts.
He said that with some of the technology indices reaching levels not seen in several months, "this is probably a good price if you're long puts to get out and take a look.
"There are probably more sellers of puts than anything," he added. "I think people had anticipated this move down and are now taking profits."
Stamer is a designated primary market maker in several technology stocks and the CBOE's technology index TXX.
The TXX was down 4.07, or 2.20 percent, at 181.22 in afternoon trading. It reached 177.93 intraday.
"This would be a good level for technology indices at least, if you're short, to cover and take another look at them over the next few weeks and months," Stamer said.
Options on individual technology stocks were among the most active at all exchanges.
At the AMEX, Intel Corp options were the most active group, led by the March 135 call, which traded about 5,850 contracts. Overall, Intel puts were busier than calls.
Intel shares were down 2-1/2 at 134-1/4 in late trade after falling to 132 intraday.

"Some of the nervous money is flowing out," Andrew Schwarz, senior partner at AGS Specialist Partners at the AMEX, said. "We're seeing a move toward puts, so people are running to protection and historically that's a bullish sign."
